title.narrative: We are able! Burundi

description.narrative: By 2025, through engagement with public authorities (formal and informal powerholders), men, women and youth with disabilities and other excluded groups, through resilient and capable local CSOs/DPOs in this fragile and conflict-affected country, are successfully influencing laws, policies, practices and norms for improved food security for all.

The We are able! program targets people (including women, men, and youth) with a disability, while, as spin-off, the program will also create opportunities for other excluded groups,3 such as vulnerable women, persons affected by leprosy, youth in general, excluded ethnic groups, internally displaced persons (IDPs) and refugees, as much as possible or necessary in the specific context. Intersectional traits often make people particularly vulnerable. Refugees with disabilities or disabled women and men of particular ethnic backgrounds often face the most severe forms of food insecurity. We are able! identifies and targets groups and individuals with particular vulnerabilities while creating synergies that allow others to benefit as well.

The activities in Burundi are part of the We are able! program in DR Congo, Burundi, Ethiopia, South Sudan, Sudan and Uganda. Food security in these countries is low. People with disabilities (PWDs) are even more likely to live in food insecure households. We are able! wants to see PWDs improving their right to food and food security by creating an enabling environment for right-to-food action at grassroots level. While PWDs are the core target group of the We are able! program, we create benefits for other excluded groups like vulnerable women, youth in general, marginalised ethnic groups and internally displaced persons (IDPs), as applicable per context.

title.narrative: SCS4 # of advocacy initiatives carried out by CSOs, for, by or with their membership/constituency
# of advocacy initiatives carried out by CSOs, for, by or with their membership/constituency

comment.narrative: 1) Croix Rouge /Branche Buganda: Lobbying for improving access to health care services targeted at partners of the Red Cross including the Government of Burundi through the Ministry of Public Health and local administration. Requesting support for vulnerable people including persons with disabilities for access to health care through the granting of Health Insurance Cards (CAM). Identification of these people with the support of the local administration, mobilization of means to have the necessary number Health Insurance Cards and distribution of these CAMs to identified beneficiaries.

title.narrative: # of advocacy initiatives carried out by CSOs, for, by or with their membership/constituency at sub-national level

comment.narrative: 1) Garukira Abamugaye b’i Mabayi: Awareness raising and lobbying for physical access to public buildings such as the hospital and the Mabayi Residence Court. 2) Garukira Abamugaye b’i Mabayi Lobbying and awareness raising against the exploitation of disabled children by forcing them to beg at the Mabayi market. Raising awareness about the need for disabled children to go to school like other children. 3) ADEPH: Providing access to sport and recreational facilities through the redevelopment of a volleyball field into a Sitting Volleyball field with the possibility of playing both disciplines. 4) ADEPH: Lobbying for the inclusion of members of ADEPH as health data collectors for Community Health Centres in Buganda commune. Enhancement of data collection capacities. Requesting for official documents listing the status as health data collectors. The lobbying has led to the recognition of the value and inclusion of persons with disabilities in the health data collection teams. 5) ADEPH: Lobbying for the enrolment of members of ADEPH as community awareness actors during a 16 day mass awareness campaign against Gender Based Violence. 6) ADEPH: Changing negative attitude towards persons with disabilities by showing they have capacities. Various activities have been organized such as friendly matches with the Bubanza sitting volleyball team. The inclusion of persons with disabilities as awareness raising actors in the local theatre group. The skills training of persons with disabilities in basketry and bakery have demonstrated the capacities of persons with disabilities. 7) Croix Rouge /Branche Buganda: The organisation has contacted local authorities and advocated for decent housing of vulnerable persons including persons with disabilities. With the help of local authorities and the Red Cross authorities construction materials were collected and the construction of decent houses for vulnerable persons and persons with disabilities was started. 8) Croix Rouge /Branche Buganda: Raising awareness and lobbying for a change of language when referring to persons with disabilities. The word "Ikimuga" is commonly used when referring to persons with disabilities. This word is degrading as it means “worthless” and “incapable”. Awareness messages were developed for persons with disabilities on their capacities and rights to development in collaboration with the OPH ADEPH and displayed during sitting volleyball matches. 9) Association pour la Réinsertion des Handicapés-Twiyunge (ARH): Identification and mobilization of persons with disabilities in other areas for the establishment of ARH-Twiyunge branches in Gatwe and Kinzanza. Mobilization of membership fees and donations received from Handicap International.

title.narrative: SCS3 # of times that CSOs succeed in creating space for CSO demands and positions through agenda setting, influencing the debate and/or creating space to engage Methodological notes
# of times that CSOs succeed in creating space for CSO demands and positions through agenda setting, influencing the debate and/or creating space to engage at sub-national level

comment.narrative: 1) Garukira Abamugaye b'i Mabayi The organisation launched a campaign directed to local authorities and community members in general to change devaluating language such as the word ''Ikimuga', which is a devaluing term for persons with disabilities, to something positive such as ''Umuntu agendana ubumuga'', meaning a disabled person or a person living with a handicap in Kirundi. The organisation has used individual and mass sensitizations through music composed by a member of the OPH. 2) Croix Rouge /Branche Buganda To reduce the ill-treatment of Albino students by other students, the organisation has raised the awareness of school directors, municipal administrator, students and teachers about the rights and needs of pupils with albinism. In line with this the organisation has also conducted community awareness-raising visits to convince parents of newly born albino children of the rights, needs and capacities of persons with albinism. 3) Association pour la Réinsertion des Handicapés-Twiyunge (ARH) This organisation is targeting other organisations to put disability inclusion on the agenda with the aim of increasing acceptance and non-discrimination of persons with disabilities. The organisation facilitates the establishment of new associations and provides support in training other associations.

title.narrative: # of times that CSOs succeed in creating space for CSO demands and positions through agenda setting, influencing the debate and/or creating space to engage at national and international level

comment.narrative: No examples found of CSOs that succeeded in creating space
